awd_titl_txt: MRI:  Acquisition of a Mass Storage System for Data Intelligence Research
awd_abstract_narration:
Data intelligence research on turning data into actionable intelligence and insights is at the heart of many disciplines, including computer science, mathematics, chemistry, business, and biology. This research instrumentation project involves the acquisition of a mass storage system to enhance the storage capacity of a High-Performance Computing (HPC) cluster.  This will enable researchers at the awardee and neighboring institutions to conduct studies in: scalable computational algorithms for big data analysis; finding answers to customized questions by reasoning over large-scale unstructured data; the development of deep learning techniques for two- and three-dimensional biological and medical image analysis; and other big data research challenges.   The instrumentation also creates an opportunity for students to participate in a variety of research and training activities related to data intelligence.

The project provides better storage capacity to process and share massive data. The system enables data intelligence research and training activities by providing flexible storage configurations, data preservation and recovery, high-performance, large-scale data operations, and secure data sharing for a broad range of projects. It supports collaboration across various universities in California, and enables faculty and students to develop modern scalable solutions to data intelligence problems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project is to acquire a mass storage system to enhance the storage capacity of the High-Performance Computing (HPC) cluster at California State Polytechnic University, Pomona (Cal Poly Pomona). With the support of the NSF MRI grant, we have one mass storage system successfully installed and connected to our campus HPC cluster, which is made accessible to all faculty and students as a campus-wide shared resource. This requested storage system substantially improves the HPC storage infrastructure at Cal Poly Pomona. We worked with the Cal Poly Pomona IT Division team to develop the usage and sharing policies of the HPC clusters and mass storage for potential users. During the award period, we have worked with our collaborators and mentored students to conduct data intelligence research projects using the HPC cluster with the mass storage system. We have also made a webinar introducing the HPC mass storage system to Cal Poly Pomona faculty and researchers, two talks to REU students in the NSF REU Site in Big Data Security and Privacy at Cal Poly Pomona, and one presentation to students in Cal Poly Pomona's Master of Science in Data Analytics (MSBA) program. The requested mass storage system has played an important role in enabling our HPC cluster to accommodate various data intelligence projects with large research data. The Cal Poly Pomona IT Division will ensure successful operations and maintenance over the expected lifetime of the mass storage system as part of our HPC cluster.
